depression.question: Finding no joy in life, or feeling like you never will again
Being lethargic or having no energy
Eating too much, or too little
Being full of nervous energy, or moving much less than usual
Oversleeping, or struggling to get to sleep
Being harsh on yourself or overly self-critical
Considering harming yourself, or committing suicide
Headaches, cramps, aches, or pains that won't go away
Loss of interest or pleasure in things you previously found enjoyable
Feeling angry, irritable, or frustrated, even over small matters
Slowed thinking, speaking, or body movements

anxiety.question: I've been unable to stay in one place - like sitting down - for any length of time
I've been very concerned about several things at one time
I've been agitated, tense, or skittish
I've been unable to feel calm or relaxed
I've struggled to control feelings of anxiety, agitation, or fear
I've felt bad-tempered, irritable, or moody
I've been afraid or panicky about bad things that might happen to myself or others

adult_adhd.question: When you have to sit down for an extended period - like at a dinner - you find yourself fidgeting or feeling uncomfortable
You feel hyperactive and like you are on autopilot
You struggle to start tasks that require you to sit down and concentrate for an extended period
You sometimes forget meetings, appointments, or events
You struggle to complete tasks or projects, even ones which are nearly complete
You find it hard to properly organize, plan, or do things in the right order

ptsd.question: I've had trouble focusing on things like reading, TV shows, or conversations
Memories of the trauma came to mind at unwanted moments
Parts of the traumatic event are hazy or difficult to remember
I've been avoiding things - like places, people, or events - that make me think about the trauma
I've felt rushes of anger or irritability
I've been on edge much more than normal, particularly when there have been other people around
I've been unable to connect to my emotions such as not being able to laugh or cry, or feel affection for those around me
I've been trying to avoid thinking about the trauma, or the way that it makes me feel
I became frightened, angry, or upset when remembering the trauma
I experienced a racing pulse, excessive sweating, shaking, or chills when remembering the trauma
I've been hyper alert, particularly in situations with lots of other people around
Memories of the trauma were so vivid I felt like they were reoccurring
I've felt detached from friends and family, or those closest to me
I'm not interested in doing things or going places that I liked to do or go to before the trauma occurred
The life goals I had before the trauma have changed or have gone entirely
Thoughts or memories of the trauma have come to me while asleep
I've struggled to get to sleep, or to stay asleep

narcissistic_personality_disorder.question: I have trouble recognizing the feelings and needs of others
I am often preoccupied with thoughts of success, power, and status
tell others about my relationships with high status people
I overestimate my achievements and talents
I undervalue the achievements of others
I feel upset when the people around me achieve success
I have trouble receiving criticism, even when it is valid
I believe I am unique, but only other special people can see that
I believe others are envious or jealous of me
I feel entitled to favorable treatment

ocd.question: To what extent were you able to exercise control over those obsessive thoughts?
To what extent were you able to exercise control over the compulsive behaviors?
How much time did you spend engaging in compulsive behaviors?

options.answer: Up to an hour a day
Most or all of the day

ocd.question: How much of the time were you able to stop yourself engaging in those compulsive behaviors?
To what extent did these thoughts make you feel distressed or upset?
How much of the time were you able to stop yourself having obsessive thoughts?
To what extent did these compulsive behaviors get in the way or your school, work, or social life?
To what extent did these thoughts get in the way or your school, work, or social life?
How much of that period was occupied by uncontrollable or obsessive thoughts?

options.answer: Up to an hour a day
Most or all of the day

ocd.question: How anxious would you have been if you had been prevented acting out the compulsive behaviors?

bipolar_disorder.question: You could not shut your mind off or stop thoughts rushing through your mind
You experienced feelings of anguish or desperation
You were much more socially active than normal, and at all hours
Your behavior was unsafe or risky in a way that wasn't normal for you
You felt exhausted or unusually fatigued
You got angry and you were aggressive or violent towards others
You talked a lot more or a lot faster than normal
You took risks with your finances which caused problems for yourself or others
Nothing could make you happy or joyful
Your sex drive was much higher than normal
You felt slower than normal, in your body or your mind, for a noticeable period of time
You were a lot more confident or self-assured than normal
You didn’t sleep very much and felt like you didn’t really need to
You felt inadequate or to blame for things
You were much more lively and energetic than normal
You became absent-minded and had difficulty focusing on tasks
You were much more productive than normal
You became so excitable or agitated that others around you were surprised by your behavior, or your behavior caused problems for you
If you agreed with several of these statements, have any of these things happened at the same time?
Have you had trouble because of these issues either in your job, at home, or in your social life?

psychosis.question: I sometimes see things that others tell me they cannot see
I sometimes feel the presence of someone around me despite being alone
I sometimes feel that someone or something else controls my thoughts
I frequently feel like other people are plotting against me
I feel that my body is different or behaves in a different way to how it used to
I frequently hear strange sounds like crashing or ringing
I have lost interest in things I used to like
I find that I experience smells or tastes that others cannot
I have seen someone's face change in front of me, or my own face has changed in the mirror
Meeting new people makes me very nervous or stressed
I sometimes hear voices that others cannot
I am not always sure if something has actually happened, or whether I imagined it
I sometimes spot hidden messages in adverts on television, in shop displays, or in how things are arranged
I get the feeling that I have lived through the present situation before, like things are repeating
Now and then I feel like I can almost hear my thoughts
I sometimes lose focus because of far-off sounds which I would not normally hear

stress.question: Became pregnant
Newborn or other addition the family
Death of life partner
Major workplace changes such as working hours or environment
Significant difference in sleep habits (considerably more or less)
Foreclosure of a mortgage or loan
Spouse starting or stopping working out of the family home
Arguing considerably more or less with partner
Significant difference in eating habits, for example changes to quantity, timing, or location
Got back together with spouse or partner
Celebrated one or more public holidays
Separation from partner
Career shift to a new sort of work
A start or end to formal education
Loss of a good friend
Workplace problems with a manager
Significant difference in general habits, for example stopping smoking, gave up drinking, or became vegan
Significant difference in frequency of family gatherings
Got a loan
Got a divorce
Child leaving the family home
Involuntarily lost your job
Retired
Significant difference in recreational habits, for example ended a longstanding hobby or started a new one
Addition of a home or business mortgage
Got married
Achieved a great personal success which you had been working toward for more than 6 months
Sex problems
Relocation for work or other reasons
Significant housing change (moving home, renovation, changes to the neighborhood)
Traffic ticket, jaywalking, or other minor legal issue
Significant difference in faith-related habits (considerably more or less)
Significant change in level of responsibility at work, either much more or much less
Death in the family
Significant difference in frequency of social activities (considerably more or less)
Significant change in financial circumstances for better or for worse
Went on vacation lasting more than a week
Time spent in jail or otherwise incarcerated
Serious injury or health issue
Moving school
Problems with partner’s parents
Change in work, like location or role
Serious family health issue
